segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.transcript: What's it like to run a $450 million company?
segments.transcript_translated: ¿Cómo es dirigir una empresa de 450 millones de dólares?

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.transcript: busy, very chaotic, quickly evolving. The AI space is blowing up right now. And so when we started the company three years ago, it was just me and two other guys just building a product that we loved. And now the team is rapidly expanding. I'm now like a manager. I'm managing a lot of people. And just the scale of problems that happen, if the app goes down, there's 500,000 people that are upset about it.
segments.transcript_translated: Estoy muy ocupado, muy caótico, evolucionando rápidamente. El espacio de la IA está explotando en este momento. Así que cuando empezamos la compañía hace tres años, era sólo yo y otros dos chicos construyendo un producto que amábamos. Y ahora el equipo se está expandiendo rápidamente. Ahora soy como un gerente. Estoy gestionando a mucha gente. Y sólo la escala de problemas que ocurren, si la aplicación cae, hay 500,000 personas que están molestas por ello.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.transcript: Yeah, that's one trend I noticed when, you know, looking at interviews of CEOs and founders. Like early on, they always say like, you know, they don't want to be in meetings. But like once they get to a certain level, basically all they do is like meetings.
segments.transcript_translated: Sí, esa es una tendencia que noté cuando, ya sabes, miré entrevistas de CEO y fundadores. Como desde el principio, siempre dicen, ya sabes, que no quieren estar en reuniones. Pero una vez que llegan a un cierto nivel, básicamente todo lo que hacen es como reuniones.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.transcript: Yep, I have personally experienced that. It's nicer if you can avoid doing a meeting and you can just solve problems with engineers by sitting next to them. I find that that's a much better use of time. But yeah, this impulse to have a meeting is something that you have to continually fight against.
segments.transcript_translated: Sí, lo he experimentado personalmente. Es mejor si puedes evitar hacer una reunión y puedes resolver problemas con los ingenieros sentándote junto a ellos. Me parece que es un mejor uso del tiempo. Pero sí, este impulso de tener una reunión es algo contra lo que tienes que luchar continuamente.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.transcript: Okay, so you mentioned that you started with three people. So how many of you are today, the total amount of employees?
segments.transcript_translated: Vale, así que mencionó que comenzó con tres personas. ¿Cuántos de ustedes son hoy, la cantidad total de empleados?

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.transcript: So currently there's like 12 of us and we expect this number to continue to grow.
segments.transcript_translated: Así que actualmente somos 12 y esperamos que este número continúe creciendo.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.transcript: Yeah, that's pretty amazing for such a big valuation. But I guess all the AI companies have pretty high valuation per employee ratios.
segments.transcript_translated: Sí, eso es increíble para una valoración tan grande, pero supongo que todas las compañías de IA tienen una valoración bastante alta por proporción de empleados.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.transcript: Yep. So I think there's a reason for this, which is we really have a very, very high bar for hiring.
segments.transcript_translated: Así que creo que hay una razón para esto, que es que tenemos un nivel muy, muy alto para contratar.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.transcript: And we've got a great emphasis and we really value talent density.
segments.transcript_translated: Y tenemos un gran énfasis y realmente valoramos la densidad de talento.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.transcript: So, you know, there are there are like these amazing companies that you hear about, whether that's how Instagram was able to to scale to this billion dollar valuation and this amazing product with I think they only had like 12 engineers. I think WhatsApp.
segments.transcript_translated: Así que, ya sabes, hay empresas como estas increíbles de las que escuchas, si es así como Instagram fue capaz de escalar a esta valoración de mil millones de dólares y este producto increíble con creo que sólo tenían como 12 ingenieros. Creo que WhatsApp.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.transcript: I think only seven actually, when they reached one billion.
segments.transcript_translated: Creo que sólo siete en realidad, cuando llegaron a mil millones.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.transcript: One billion, yeah.
segments.transcript_translated: Un billón, sí.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.transcript: And then you get stories of WhatsApp and how far they were able to get with as few engineers. And I just think it's very clear being a software engineer myself that a talented, just a small team of really talented people can really, really build a huge product and can have a really big impact. And if you just randomly add people to the team, it actually slows things down and it causes many more problems than it solves.
segments.transcript_translated: Y luego se obtienen historias de WhatsApp y lo lejos que fueron capaces de llegar con tan pocos ingenieros. Y creo que es muy claro que siendo un ingeniero de software yo mismo que un equipo talentoso, sólo un pequeño equipo de personas realmente talentosas puede realmente, realmente construir un producto enorme y puede tener un impacto realmente grande. Y si se añade a la gente al azar al equipo, en realidad ralentiza las cosas y causa muchos más problemas de los que resuelve.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.transcript: Yeah, I think this is one of the biggest mistakes, like, first time entrepreneurs make. They're always in a rush to, like, grow the company and, you know, hire as many people as possible. But if you hire the wrong kind of people, then, you know, doing some restructuring later on, that's, like, 10 times more painful than just, you know, doing more interviews and really finding that core person that fits exactly what you need. Yeah.
segments.transcript_translated: Sí, creo que este es uno de los errores más grandes que cometen los emprendedores por primera vez. Siempre tienen prisa por hacer crecer la empresa y, ya sabes, contratar a tantas personas como sea posible. Pero si contratas al tipo equivocado de personas, entonces, ya sabes, hacer alguna reestructuración más tarde, eso es, como, 10 veces más doloroso que simplemente, ya sabes, hacer más entrevistas y realmente encontrar la persona principal que se adapta exactamente a lo que necesitas.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.transcript: Yeah, yeah. Okay, so let's take a step back before Chai, so you went to Cambridge and then you had you found it a hedge fund. So what was that like?
segments.transcript_translated: Vale, vamos a dar un paso atrás antes de Chai, así que fuiste a Cambridge y luego lo hiciste encontrar un fondo de cobertura. ¿Y cómo fue eso?

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.transcript: cool. So coming out of Cambridge I studied economics, this is back in 2012 and machine learning was really just coming into the mainstream, it was just coming into production in industrial settings and there was clearly an opportunity to take all these algorithms, neural networks, random trees and kind of apply them to a financial setting and so you know again me and just a couple friends we got together and we just started getting data sets, started training neural networks and seeing if we could predict the price of assets in the future and after about a year or so I started to work on a new project called the Smart Network. So in about a year we'd sort of built this strategy that was that was making a few hundred thousand pounds a year which when I was 22 years old was a lot of money and was you know it was really I felt that was a really great success and so we just kept doubling down and so any money that we made we sort of reinvested in the business by hiring more engineers, more talented people, you know the first people I'd hire were my friends from Cambridge and some of them did really well, some of them did really badly and that caused me to sort of begin to dig into why is it that some people can be smart and add loads of value and other people could be smart and not add value and so as you described earlier on first-time managers, first-time founders will just try and hire people just quickly trying to collect people and throw bodies at the problem and then with that you'll encounter a lot of problems. And a lot of frictions and it's really about finding the right person to address the specific problem at hand and so yeah that hedge fund was called Seamless Capital. I started it with basically I had I probably had about $100,000 of money that I'd won throughout college playing poker. Nice. And I kind of took those poker winnings and scaled it up to now it's still running today it's a very profitable company it makes about five million pounds a year and it's all AI and machine learning. So
segments.transcript_translated: cool Así que saliendo de Cambridge estudié economía, esto es de vuelta en 2012 y el aprendizaje automático estaba realmente entrando en la corriente principal, estaba entrando en producción en entornos industriales y allí Así que en aproximadamente un año habíamos construido una estrategia que era que ganaba unos cientos de miles de libras al año que cuando tenía 22 años era mucho dinero y era realmente lo que sentía Y muchas fricciones y realmente se trata de encontrar a la persona adecuada para abordar el problema específico en cuestión y así que sí que ese fondo de cobertura se llamaba Capital sin costuras Lo comencé con básicamente tenía probablemente tenía alrededor de $100,000 de dinero que había ganado durante la universidad jugando al póker Nice Y en cierto modo tomé esas ganancias de póquer y las amplié hasta ahora sigue funcionando hoy en día es una empresa muy rentable gana alrededor de 5 millones de libras al año y todo es IA y aprendizaje automático Así que...

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.transcript: Like 2012, that's like even before the deep learning revolution, basically.
segments.transcript_translated: Como en 2012, es como incluso antes de la revolución del aprendizaje profundo, básicamente.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.transcript: It's just on the cusp. It's just as it was beginning. It really was the first. The big textbooks were being written. Andrew Wing's Coursera course was just coming out. Yeah, it was a really exciting time.
segments.transcript_translated: Es sólo en la cúspide, es justo como estaba comenzando, fue realmente el primero, los grandes libros de texto estaban siendo escritos, el curso de Andrew Wing de Coursera estaba saliendo. Sí, fue un momento muy emocionante.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.transcript: it was beginning.
segments.transcript_translated: Estaba empezando.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.transcript: So I was doing, I was doing, um, neural networks before dropout existed.
segments.transcript_translated: Así que estaba haciendo, estaba haciendo, um, redes neuronales antes de que el abandono existiera.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.transcript: So, okay, so what made you like originally get into AI? Because you mentioned you studied economics. So, you know, that's... So...
segments.transcript_translated: Entonces, ¿qué te hizo gustar inicialmente entrar en IA? porque mencionaste que estudiaste economía.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.transcript: So coming from the UK, really at that time and even still today, like most of the smart, you know, industrious people really end up finding themselves in finance. It's kind of is the UK is so much smaller than America. And it's kind of like London, the city of London. That's our one big like tech hub. And so finance is an exciting space where, you know, you've got all these really smart mathematicians, physicists who take all these techniques on how to model stuff, how to predict things, and they apply it to financial assets. And so it was very natural when, you know, all my peers were going into places like Jane Street or going into places like Citadel. You know, even I studied to like pass some round one. I've done interviews at a couple hedge funds and algorithmic trading firms. So it's really that was just the direction that people in the UK work towards. Very much like people on the West Coast. They all have in their mind they want to do a tech startup or be involved in tech in somehow. That's kind of the culture which I was surrounded by in the UK at the time when I graduated.
segments.transcript_translated: Así que viniendo del Reino Unido, realmente en ese momento e incluso hoy, como la mayoría de las personas inteligentes, sabes, trabajadoras realmente terminan encontrándose en las finanzas Es como si el Reino Unido es mucho más pequeño que Estados Unidos Y es como Londres, la ciudad de Londres. Ese es nuestro único gran centro tecnológico Y así que las finanzas son un espacio emocionante donde, ya sabes, tienes a todos estos matemáticos realmente inteligentes, físicos que toman todas estas técnicas de cómo modelar cosas, cómo predecir cosas, y que Y así que era muy natural cuando, ya sabes, todos mis compañeros iban a lugares como Jane Street o a lugares como Citadel Incluso yo estudié para pasar una ronda. He hecho entrevistas en un par de fondos de cobertura y empresas de comercio algorítmico Así que realmente esa fue la dirección en la que la gente en el Reino Unido trabaja hacia Muy parecido a la gente de la costa oeste Todos tienen en mente que quieren hacer una startup tecnológica o estar involucrados en la tecnología de alguna manera Esa es la cultura que me rodeó en el Reino Unido cuando me gradué.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.transcript: So then what made you want to change direction?
segments.transcript_translated: Entonces, ¿qué te hizo querer cambiar de dirección?

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.transcript: Cool. So I really, really loved my first business. I had a lot of freedom. I didn't have any external investors. It was always just either my money or the team's money that we'd sort of pulled together. And so we were free to make our own mistakes, make our own decisions. We didn't have any customers. It was just our own capital that we would trade using our own algorithms. And it was very, very simple. And, you know, I built really strong relationships with the engineers I worked with. And we had a really talented team. And as I approached my 30th birthday, I kind of just reflected on the last 10 years. And I thought, you know, how have I grown? What is it that I've achieved? And then what would my next 10 years look like? And, you know, the way I saw it is. You know, I was in the business business. I was in the business business. It was very, very challenging to build the company. You know, I remember being something like 26 years old and losing like a million pounds over the course of a month, which was like a significant amount of my wealth, right? And what kind of assets?
segments.transcript_translated: Cool Así que me encantó mucho mi primer negocio. Tenía mucha libertad. No tenía ningún inversor externo. Siempre fue mi dinero o el dinero del equipo lo que hemos reunido. Y así fuimos libres de cometer nuestros propios errores, tomar nuestras propias decisiones No teníamos clientes. Era sólo nuestro propio capital que comerciaríamos usando nuestros propios algoritmos Y fue muy, muy simple. Y, ya sabes, construí relaciones muy fuertes con los ingenieros con los que trabajé Y teníamos un equipo muy talentoso. Y cuando me acerqué a mi 30 cumpleaños, pensé en los últimos 10 años. Y pensé, ya sabes, cómo he crecido ¿Qué he logrado? Y entonces, ¿cómo se verían mis próximos 10 años? Y, ya sabes, la forma en que lo vi es Sabes, yo estaba en el negocio Yo estaba en el negocio. Fue muy, muy difícil construir la empresa. Recuerdo tener 26 años y perder un millón de libras en el transcurso de un mes, que era una cantidad significativa de mi riqueza, ¿verdad? Y qué tipo de activos

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.transcript: What kind of assets were you trading?
segments.transcript_translated: ¿Qué tipo de activos estabas intercambiando?

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.transcript: So we were actually betting on sports markets.
segments.transcript_translated: Así que estábamos apostando en los mercados deportivos.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01
segments.transcript: Interesting.
segments.transcript_translated: Es muy interesante.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.transcript: and you know and that's but that's just one example you know I remember being 24 and not you know not winning any money or earning any money over the course of nine months or something right whenever you're a founder whenever you're building a business in fact in life if you're doing anything that's challenging there's always going you know or anything that pushes that pushes yourself beyond what you're currently capable of doing you're going to fail you're going to be forced to grow um and so I looked over these 10 years and I really loved it it was I loved all the ups I loved the downs and through I felt that I'd grown a lot um and the outcome was a loop a very lucrative business it was lucrative for everyone that was involved and I just thought what did I want to do the next 10 years of my life and I could keep running this sort of um a sort of financial entity which really just all it does is increase my income and I'm not sure what it's actually going to do but I'm going to makes money right which isn't bad you know it's pretty fun um and i and i just thought that seemed very easy it seemed like that was the easy way i'd kind of been through all that hardship i'd learned all of those lessons and i just asked myself the question like what would what would it look like if i wanted to just build the biggest thing i could possibly build have the biggest impact i could possibly have um and just really stretch myself way beyond what i thought i was capable of doing and then with that it was it i had a lot of knowledge about ai uh because all of the all of the trades that we were doing it was entirely informed by ai and machine learning um and so in 2018 um 2019 it was increasingly obvious that large language models were a totally transformational technology um um and i remember just being very aware like
segments.transcript_translated: y ya sabes y eso es pero ese es sólo un ejemplo sabes que recuerdo que soy 24 y no sabes no ganar ningún dinero o ganar ningún dinero en el transcurso de nueve meses o algo así correcto cada vez que

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00
segments.transcript: this technology is going to change the world and is going to be something that every person interacts with on a daily basis and i thought to myself it's this there's going to have to exist a platform where not just a single model not a huge monolithic model like the sorts which open ai are creating or the sorts that google are creating but i imagine a world where everyone is going to be there are so many talented people spread across the world they're not just in silicon valley or they're not just in stanford or cambridge but there's talented ai researchers and there's talented engineers across the world and so we'll see many many interesting unique language models and they'll have to exist a platform where they all come together and consumers are able to find the appropriate language model to interact with and so my initial vision was something like maybe it'd be like google where people would kind of search you know i want to speak to a recipe you know i'll speak to a language model that's like a great chef and i thought well maybe there'll be people whose sole existence will be to create the best recipe and chef-like language model
segments.transcript_translated: esta tecnología va a cambiar el mundo y va a ser algo con lo que cada persona interactúa a diario y pensé en mí mismo que es esto va a tener que existir una plataforma donde no sólo un modelo único no un modelo monolítico enorme como el tipo que abierto ai están creando o el tipo que Google están creando pero me imagino un mundo donde todo el mundo va a estar hay tantas personas talentosas repartidas en todo el mundo no son sólo en Silicon Valley o no son sólo en Stanford o Cambridge pero hay investigadores talentosos ai y hay ingenieros talentosos en todo el mundo y así vamos a ver muchos modelos de lenguaje único interesante y tendrán que existir una plataforma donde todos se reúnen y los consumidores son capaces de encontrar el modelo de lenguaje apropiado para interactuar y hablar así que mi visión inicial fue algo que tal vez sea donde la gente me gustaría buscar un tipo de receta y un mejor modelo de cocinero que tal vez sea el mejor modelo de la que la gente pueda pensar y hablar
